docs.lead_paragraph: There was little need for the 24-second clock. A 10-second clock might have been more appropriate today for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, in which the East defeated the West, 132-123. Julius Erving of the Philadelphia 76ers scored 25 points and was voted the most valuable player. The East's fourth consecutive victory was theater of improvisation, creative one-on-one open-floor basketball at its best. In the first period, Earvin (Magic) Johnson raced down the right side on a fast break into the lane, made a ballet move, then a full spin and a scoop shot. As the ball dropped through the hoop, Johnson was fouled by Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics and made the free throw. He finished with 17 points to go with his All-Star Game record of 16 assists, 11 in the first half. He broke Oscar Robertson's 1961 record of 14.

docs.lead_paragraph: There was a huge grin on Maurice Lucas's face, which appeared to spell out vindication as the former Knick forward explained his feelings today about being a starter on the West team in Sunday's 33d annual National Basketball Association All-Star Game at the Forum. ''I'm very excited,'' said the 31-year-old Lucas, who was traded by the Knicks to the Phoenix Suns before the season began. ''This is my fourth All-Star Game, but it feels like the excitement of my first. Call it a feeling of being reborn again or, a more likely reason, it's the answer to a lot of people who may have put the nails in my coffin prematurely.''

docs.lead_paragraph: year-old Great Neck theater with a star-studded but short-lived stage past - and a more recent history as a movie house - opened last fall. The attractions were a series of two-night stands: an opera, a revue, a ballet, a chamber music recital and a couple of children's shows. Actually, the New Globe Theater production of Oscar Wilde's ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' which runs until next Sunday and is being presented by a new management, represents a booking of another sort. This is Stuart Vaughan's itinerant group of professional actors, who are currently based in Westchester. Still, a play is a play, a play is what a playhouse is meant to house, and ''Earnest'' is some play.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN its struggle to secure a foothold in the regional theater firmament, the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., may be reversing a stereotype, and devising a new strategy for survival. Generally, new plays mean high risk; classics and revivals are considered to be the crowd pleasers. However, there has been a paucity of original home-grown plays on Broadway, where the theater season is, by critical consensus, grim as well as sparse. ''Broadway has become more geared to event presentation, as opposed to plays,'' said the Hartman's executive director, Harris Goldman. ''Besides, our community, which is close to New York, has become accustomed to new plays, and they look forward to them. We can't thrive on classics alone.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for a venerable black trade union leader, whose trial here on charges of murder and terrorism is about to enter its third year, did not go through the motions of applying for his release on bail this week after the last potential witness against him recanted an earlier statement. There could be no argument for bail because one of the laws on which the unionist, Oscar Mpetha, is charged in a 31-count indictment gives the judge no discretion whatsoever on the matter of bail if the state opposes it. So Mr. Mpetha, who is 73 years old and infirm from a diabetes condition that could force the amputation of his left leg, was hauled back to prison Thursday at the end of the 207th day of the trial, one of the longest in the annals of South African criminal law. An official of the mainly black Food and Canning Workers Union, he is standing trial with 18 young blacks, most of whom are a full halfcentury younger than he is. He testified that he knew none of them before his arrest on Aug. 13, 1980. The state contends that he whipped them up into a frenzy of antiwhite racial feeling and instigated a riot in which the cars of two passing white motorists were stoned and set aflame; the motorists were both killed, one of them apparently by stab wounds.

docs.lead_paragraph: At one time, the notion of a Swiss ballet company seemed comparable in importance to the idea of a Swiss navy. In fact, a widely used reference book such as the Dance Encyclopedia (edited by Anatole Chujoy and P.W. Manchester) does not even have a ''Dance in Switzerland'' entry as it does for many other countries. Until the Basel Ballet's recent appearance as the fourth European company in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet International'' series, no Swiss ballet company seems to have performed in the United States. It would nonetheless be misleading to suggest that the Swiss have played no role at all in theatrical dance. The very geographical and historical conditions that may have militated against the development of a major ballet tradition seem to have been a factor in a Swiss contribution to the development of Central European modern dance.

docs.lead_paragraph: The moment he appears on the screen, audiences start to laugh. Tall and skinny, constantly leaning with an inquisitive nose into a nonexistent wind, he lurches hither and yon, like some spastic bird, in a bouncing, loping stride that rolls from heel to toe. Jacques Tati has been compared to such earlier masters of cinema mime as Chaplin and Buster Keaton. He died last November, but the hilarity lives on in the handful of films, thickly packed with sight and sound gags, that he wrote and directed and in which he starred. For years, nobody was able to see his films: the French banks seized them when Tati was unable to pay his debts.

docs.lead_paragraph: As he left the Federal courtroom Monday in Jacksonville, Fla., just after the jury acquitted his client, Jamiel (Jimmy) Chagra, of conspiring to murder Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., the defense lawyer, Oscar Goodman, said: ''The verdict speaks more eloquently than anything I could say. I can't believe it.'' It was clearly an expression of exultation rather than disbelief, but there was reason to take the comment literally. Just seven weeks earlier, a jury in San Antonio found three other defendants, including Mr. Chagra's wife, Elizabeth, guilty of six counts of planning, carrying out and trying to cover up the judge's murder.
